definition.name: NXellipsometry

symbols.doc: Variables used throughout the document, e.g. dimensions and important parameters

symbol.name: N_wavelength
symbol.doc: Size of the energy / wavelength vector used

symbol.name: N_variables
symbol.doc: How many variables are saved in a measurement (e.g. Psi and Delta, Mueller matrix)

definition.doc:
Ellipsometry, complex systems, up to variable angle spectroscopy.
Information on ellipsometry is provided, e.g. in: - H. Fujiwara, Spectroscopic ellipsometry: principles and applications, John Wiley & Sons, 2007. - R. M. A. Azzam and N. M. Bashara, Ellipsometry and Polarized Light, North-Holland Publishing Company, 1977. - H. G. Tompkins and E. A. Irene, Handbook of Ellipsometry, William Andrew, 2005.
Open acces sources: - https://www.angstromadvanced.com/resource.asp - https://pypolar.readthedocs.io/en/latest/

group.doc:

field.name: definition
field.doc: An application definition for ellipsometry.

attribute.name: version
attribute.doc: Version number to identify which definition of this application definition was used for this entry/data.

attribute.name: url
attribute.doc: URL where to find further material (documentation, examples) relevant to the application definition

field.name: experiment_identifier
field.doc: Unique identifier of the experiment, such as a (globally persistent) unique identifier. i) The identifier is usually defined by the facility or principle investigator. ii) The identifier enables to link experiments to e.g. proposals.

field.name: experiment_description
field.doc: A free-text description of the experiment. What is the aim of the experiment? The general procedure.

field.name: start_time
field.doc: Start time of the experiment. UTC offset should be specified.

field.name: program
field.doc: Commercial or otherwise defined given name to the program that was used to generate the results file(s) with measured data and metadata (or a link to the instrument software).

attribute.name: version
attribute.doc: Either version with build number, commit hash, or description of a (online) repository where the source code of the program and build instructions can be found so that the program can be configured in such a way that result files can be created ideally in a deterministic manner.

group.name: operator
group.doc: Contact information of at least the user of the instrument or the investigator who performed this experiment. Adding multiple users if relevant is recommended.

field.name: name
field.doc: Name of the user.

field.name: affiliation
field.doc: Name of the affiliation of the user at the point in time when the experiment was performed.

field.name: address
field.doc: Full address (street, street number, ZIP, city, country) of the user's affiliation.

field.name: email
field.doc: Email address of the user.

field.name: orcid
field.doc: Author ID defined by https://orcid.org/.

field.name: telephone_number
field.doc: Official telephone number of the user.

group.doc: General properties of the ellipsometry equipment

field.name: model
field.doc: The name of the instrument

attribute.name: version
attribute.doc: The used version of the hardware if available. If not a commercial instrument use date of completion of the hardware.

field.name: company
field.doc: Name of the company which build the instrument

field.name: construction_year
field.doc: ISO8601 date when the instrument was constructed. UTC offset should be specifiec.

field.name: software
field.doc: Name (e.g. commercial) of the software that was used for the measurement

attribute.name: version
attribute.doc: Version and build number or commit hash of the software source code

field.name: light_source
field.doc: Specify the used light source. Multiple selection possible.

field.name: other_light_source
field.doc: If you specified 'other' as light source type, please write down what it is.

field.name: focussing_probes
field.doc: Were focussing probes (lenses) used or not?

field.name: data_correction
field.doc: Were the recorded data corrected by the window effects of the lenses or not?

field.name: angular_spread
field.doc: Specify the angular spread caused by the focussing probes

field.name: ellipsometry_type
field.doc: What type of ellipsometry was used? See Fujiwara Table 4.2

field.name: calibration_status
field.doc: Was a calibration done. If yes, when was it done?

group.name: calibration
group.doc: Ellipsometers require regular calibration to adjust the hardware parameters for proper zero values and background light compensation.

field.name: calibration_time
field.doc: If calibtration status is 'calibration time provided', specify the ISO8601 datum when calibration was last performed before this measurement. UTC offset should be specified.

group.name: calibration_data
group.doc:
Arrays which provide the measured calibration data. Multiple sets are possible, e.g. Psi and delta measured on an e.g. silicon calibration waver, and the straight-through data.
We recommend to
provide data that is measured under the same settings
as the measurement was performed, that is if Psi and delta are measured for your data, also provide Psi and delta here. And use the same wavelenghts as there."

field.name: calibration_data_type
field.doc: What data was recorded for the calibration, The number of variables (N_variables) have to be set to the number of provided data columns accordingly, e.g. psi/delta -> N_variables= 2, Jones vector: N_variables = 4, Mueller martix -> N_variables= 16, etc.

field.name: calibration_angle_of_incidence
field.doc: angle(s) of incidence used during the calibration measurement (excluding straight through mode)

field.name: calibration_wavelength
field.doc: The wavelength or equivalent values (which are inter-convertible). The importer should convert all to one unit, and make the others accessible. Historically, energy is used in eV, but for visible spectroscopy wavelength is more common, for IR wave numbers in 1/cm units. Possibly use the same type of data as for the measurement!

field.name: calibration_data
field.doc: Calibration is performed on a reference surface (usually silicon wafer with well defined oxide layer) at a number of angles, then in a straight through mode (transmission in air).

field.name: calibration_sample
field.doc: Free-text to describe which sample was used for calibration, e.g. silicon wafer with 25 nm thermal oxide layer.

field.name: angle_of_incidence
field.doc: Incident angle of the beam vs. the normal of the bottom reflective (substrate) surface in the sample

group.name: stage
group.doc: Sample stage, holding the sample at a specific position in X,Y,Z (Cartesian) coordinate system and at an orientation defined by three Euler angles (alpha, beta, gamma). The stage may be motorized or manual, special for liquids or gas environment.

field.name: description
field.doc: A free-text field to provide information about the stage.

group.doc: The stage coordinate system vs. the incident beam. The Z-axis of the stage is considered to point along the normal of the substrate (bottom reflecting surface) from the stage towards the general direction of the light source. The beam comes with angle of incidence towards this Z-axis, but in opposite direction, thus they are connected with a rotation of 180 - angle of incidence (in degrees). This transformation brings us from the NEXUS coordinates to the stage coordinates. Then provide the set of translations (if there are any). These all have a vector defining their relative direction in the current coordinate system. (This current coordinate system changes with every transformation if you set the parameter 'depends' to the name of the previous step.) Last, provide the rotations of the sample

field.name: alternative
field.doc: If there is no motorized stage, we should at least qualify where the beam hits the sample and in what direction the sample stands in a free-text description, e.g. 'center of sample, long edge parallel to plane of incidence'.

group.name: window
group.doc: For environmental measurements, the environment (liquid, vapor, vacuum etc.) is enclosed in a cell or cryostat, which has windows both in the direction of the source and the detector (looking from the sample). These windows also add a phase shift to the light altering the measured signal. This shift has to be corrected based on measuring a known sample in the environmental cell.

field.name: material
field.doc: The material of the window

field.name: thickness
field.doc: Thickness of the window

field.name: orientation_angle
field.doc: Angle of the window normal (outer) vs. the substrate normal (similar to the angle of incidence).

group.name: reference_data
group.doc: Recorded data that can be used to calculate the window effect. Typically this is the substrate (e.g. silicon with thermal oxide layer) in air without window and in a known medium with the window.

field.name: reference_sample
field.doc: What sample was used to estimate the window effect.

field.name: reference_wavelength
field.doc: Use the same wavelengths at which all other measurements are recorded

field.name: data
field.doc: Recorded data of a reference surface with and without window / medium.

group.doc: Which type of detector was used, and what is known about it? A detector can be a photomultiplier (PMT), a CCD in a camera, an array in a spectrometer. If so, the whole detector unit goes in here.

field.name: detector_type
field.doc: What kind of detector module is used, e.g. CCD-spectrometer, CCD camera, PMT, photodiode, etc.

field.name: other_detector
field.doc: If you specified 'other' as detector type, please write down what it is.

field.name: integration_time
field.doc: Integration time for the measurement. Single number or array if it was varied.

field.name: revolution
field.doc: Define how many rotations of the rotating element were taken into account per spectrum.

field.name: rotating_element
field.doc: Define which elements rotates, e.g. polarizer or analyzer.

field.name: fixed_revolution
field.doc: rotation rate, if the revolution does not change during the measurement.

field.name: variable_revolution
field.doc: Specify maximum and minimum values for the revolution.

group.doc: Properties of the sample, its history, the sample environment and experimental conditions (e.g. surrounding medium, temperature, pressure etc.), along with the data (data type, wavelength array, measured data).

field.name: atom_types
field.doc: Use Hill's system for listing elements of the periodic table which are inside or attached to the surface of the specimen and thus relevant from a scientific point. The purpose of this field is to allow materials database to parse the relevant elements without having to interpret the sample history or other fields.

field.name: sample_name
field.doc: Descriptive name of the sample

field.name: sample_history
field.doc: Ideally, a reference to the location or a unique (globally persistent) identifier (e.g.) of e.g. another file which gives as many as possible details of the material, its microstructure, and its thermo-chemo-mechanical processing/preparation history. In the case that such a detailed history of the sample is not available, use this field as a free-text description to specify details of the sample and its preparation.

field.name: preparation_date
field.doc: ISO 8601 date with time zone specified. UTC offset should be specifiec.

field.name: layer_structure
field.doc: Qualitative description of the layer structure for the sample. For example: Si/native oxide/thermal oxide/polymer/peptide

field.name: data_identifier
field.doc: An identifier to correlate data to the experimental conditions, if several were used in this measurement; typically an index of 0 - N

field.name: data_type
field.doc: Select which type of data was recorded, for example Psi and Delta (see: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ellipsometry#Data_acquisition). It is possible to have multiple selections. Data types may also be converted to each other, e.g. a Mueller matrix contains N,C,S data as well. This selection defines how many columns (N_variables) are stored in the data array.

field.name: wavelength
field.doc: Wavelength value(s) used for the measurement. An array of 1 or more elements. Length defines N_wavelength

field.name: measured_data
field.doc: Resulting data from the measurement, described by data type. Minimum two columns containing Psi and delta, or for the normalized Mueller matrix, it may be 16 (or 15 if 1,1 is all 1).

field.name: data_error
field.doc: Specified uncertainties (errors) of the data described by data type. The structure is the same as for the measured data.

field.name: time_points
field.doc: An array of relative time points if a time series was recorded

field.name: medium
field.doc: Describe what was the medium above or around the sample. The common model is built up from substrate to the medium on the other side. Both boundaries are assumed infinite in the model. Here define the name of the material (e.g. water, air, etc.).

field.name: medium_refractive_indices
field.doc: Array of pairs of complex refractive indices of the medium for every measured wavelength. Only necessary if the measurement was performed not in air, or something very well known, e.g. high purity water. Specify the complex refractive index: n + ik

field.name: environment_conditions
field.doc: External parameters that have influenced the sample.

field.name: number_of_runs
field.doc: How many measurements were done varying the parameters? This forms an extra dimension beyond incident angle, time points and energy / wavelength (this is the length of the 4th dimension of the data). Defaults to 1.

field.name: varied_parameters
field.doc: Indicates which parameter was changed. Its definition must exist below. The specified variable has to be number_of_runs long, providing the parameters for each data set.

group.name: optical_excitation
group.doc: Was the sample modified using an optical source? Describe in this group the parameters of the optical excitation used.

field.name: excitation_source
field.doc: Specify the source for the external excitation

field.name: excitation_wavelength
field.doc: Wavelength value(s) or the range used for excitation. In cases of continuous laser radiation a value or a set of values may do but for other illumination types, such as pulsed lasers, or lamps, a range may describe the source better.

field.name: broadening
field.doc: Specify the FWHM of the excitation

field.name: excitation_type
field.doc: CW or pulsed excitation

field.name: pulse_length
field.doc: Duration of one laser pulse.

field.name: repetition_rate
field.doc: Repetition rate of the laser.

group.name: excitation_duration
group.doc: How long was the sample excited.

field.name: pulse_energy
field.doc: The integrated energy of light pulse.

field.name: excitation_power
field.doc: The power of one laser pulse.

field.name: voltage
field.doc: Specify the voltage if the spectra were taken under bias

field.name: temperature
field.doc: Temperature of the sample (sample holder, medium)

field.name: pH
field.doc: pH of medium (measured or set)

field.name: pressure
field.doc: Pressure of the environment of the sample.

group.name: derived_parameters
group.doc: What parameters are derived from the above data.

field.name: depolarization
field.doc: Light loss due to depolarization as a value in [0-1].

group.name: plot
group.doc: A default view of the data, in this case Psi vs. wavelength and the angles of incidence. If Psi does not exist, use other Müller matrix elements, such as N, C and S.

attribute.name: axes
attribute.doc: We recommend to use wavelength as a default attribute, but it can be replaced in the case of not full spectral ellipsometry to any suitable parameter along the X-axis.
